verb.description: Make or allow (something) to become thoroughly wet by immersing it in liquid.
examples: soak the beans overnight in water

verb.description: Impose heavy charges or taxation on.
examples: few of us common people care how much tax Congress soaks on racing motorboats

noun.description: An act of immersing someone or something in liquid for a period of time.
examples: I'm looking forward to a long soak in the tub
his daughter stayed up to put the old soak to bed

phrases: he soaked himself in the music of Mozart
I tried to soak myself in the story, to let the notes and phrases marinate in my head.
He grew up soaking himself in the traditional Greek music.
He went about researching the war meticulously, soaking himself in the plentiful documentary material from this most media-infiltrated of conflicts.
He had soaked himself in all his books from the intervening years.
origin: Old English socian become saturated with a liquid by immersion; related to sūcan to suck.
